Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Studies for Sensor and Biosensor Development
Award.AbstractNarration: Auburn University will provide 10 summer internships to undergraduates for participation in an REU Site Program sponsored by NSF in collaboration with the Department of Defense through the Awards to Stimulate and Support Undergraduate Research Experiences (ASSURE) program. This multi-disciplinary, multi-departmental REU program is open to all undergraduates enrolled in Biology, Chemistry, and Engineering. Students will conduct an independent research on the development of sensors and biosensors. The program will emphasize hands-on research experiences. Students will participate in weekly seminars to understand how sensors can be used in different areas of biology and engineering. The program will also provide preparation for graduate school, discussion on ethics in science, and social activities to foster the integration of students into the research environment. Upon completion of the projects, all students will communicate their results through poster presentations. Students will also be encouraged to publish their findings in different scientific research journals. A student database will be maintained to contact students and monitor their progress after they have completed the program. Women, underrepresented minorities and first generation college students from institutions serving minorities or from institutions with limited research opportunities are especially encouraged to apply. All stipends, room, board and travel expenses are provided. For more information visit our website at http://www.ag.auburn.edu/nsfbiosensors/, or contact the Program Director, Dr. Omar Oyarzabal, at oyarzoa@auburn.edu or 334-844-2608.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2008 through 2010, 30 students participated in the REU Site: Interdisciplinary Studies for Sensor and Biosensor Development. Students performed research in a variety of biology related topics, including artificial intelligence to develop robots, the production of shape memory polyurethanes, the generation of single-stranded DNA by asymmetric polymerase chain reaction assays, and the use of laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy to identify foodborne pathogenic bacteria. Some of the key findings from the students' research efforts are: 1) cellulose nanocrystals coated with polyaniline may provide an improvement in the production of shape memory polyurethanes. This research shows that hydrogels containing temperature-sensitive macromolecular memory could be employed for recognition applications in biosensors; 2) the generation of single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) by asymmetric polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays and real-time PCR has low productivity, but the technique may be used for the validation of DNA probes attached to optical sensors; and 3) polyoxometalates combined with metals, mainly cobalt and ruthenium, increase their catalyst functions when assembled in using the layer-by-layer method. and may improve the efficiency of chemical sensors. Seminars on biosensor, professional development and ethics helped students prepare for graduate school. Students learned to make poster presentations and to answer questions about their research during the presentation of their posters. This program achieved its goals of promoting research within women and minorities and encouraging students to pursue graduate degree programs. The students and their mentors generated several presentations in national, professional meetings and refereed journal publications. Several students switched programs to complete a bachelor of science in preparation for a career in science and technology. More than 50% of the participants are pursuing or are applying to pursue graduate programs, and one student has been awarded a Graduate Research Fellowship from NSF to complete a graduate degree program in neuroscience in a prestigious university.
